awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: CIP: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Mobile Security Education by Creating Eureka Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid development and rollout of mobile infrastructure and applications not only bring convenience to people's daily lives, but also give birth to threats that can jeopardize each individual's privacy and national security. Therefore, it is critical to train and educate the future workforce on the fundamental aspects of mobile security relevant to advanced cyberinfrastructure, and to improve their ability to identify, prevent, and respond to emerging threats. This project designs and develops a wide variety of intriguing and challenging hands-on laboratories that aim to create Eureka Experiences in reference to the "aha!" moment of understanding a previously incomprehensible concept. Such an illuminating learning experience is created by incorporating Inquiry-Based Learning (IBL) activities to hands-on laboratories. Overall, this project meets the pressing and essential needs in the Computer Science and Information Technology curricula, has a strong impact on developing the future workforce' core competencies and preparedness in mobile security related to advanced cyberinfrastructure, and helps advance national security.

In this project, three types of hands-on laboratories are designed and developed: i) Exploratory; ii) Core; and, iii) Advanced. The primary purpose of exploratory labs is to spark the interests of high school and community college students from diverse backgrounds to pursue a career in cybersecurity in mobile ecosystems related to advanced cyberinfrastructure. Core labs help prepare both undergraduate and graduate students in STEM for productive cybersecurity careers by enabling enduring understanding of key security concepts and technologies through hands-on practice in an interactive setting. Advanced labs assist future research workforce development by not only introducing emerging security technologies and threats, but also inspiring student research in related fields. In addition, a universal lab platform that is affordable and flexible is designed and developed. This project helps develop core competencies in a number of areas relevant to advanced cyberinfrastructure including how to secure mobile devices and wireless systems, protect large scale and streaming data from mobile and other sources, ensure user privacy, and prevent intrusion. By engaging all stakeholders during the development process, this project increases the likelihood of wide adoption of the developed materials by academic and professional communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The world is moving rapidly to mobile computing - many of us are constantly on their wireless devices such as smartphones. Mobile networks and applications not only bring convenience to our daily lives, but also give birth to threats that can jeopardize everyone?s privacy and security. Therefore, it is critical to train and educate the future workforce on the fundamental aspects of mobile security, and to improve their ability to identify, prevent, and respond to threats and attacks. The field of mobile security includes a treasure-trove of elegant concepts and clever techniques. However, many of these concepts and techniques are surprisingly difficult to comprehend. Hence, the ultimate goals of this project are to design and develop a variety of intriguing and challenging hands-on labs to advance mobile security training and education. 

In this project, we have developed a series hands-on mobile security labs termed as the Eureka lab series, which refers to the ?aha!? moment of understanding a previously incomprehensible concept. The Eureka lab series covers a wide range of mobile security topics including Wi-Fi security standards (WEP, WPA, WPA2 and WPA3), media access control (MAC) protocol security, wireless survey and reconnaissance, data privacy, Internet of things (IoT) security, etc. For each lab, we provided detailed instructions and reference materials. In addition, we have developed a generic lab platform/environment for carrying our developed labs, which accommodates learners with different resource limitations. Lastly, we have developed a lab publishing and usage analysis platform. The platform has been up and running, which is available at https://eurekalabs.net/. 

The project provides many valuable resources for understanding mobile security threats/attacks and practicing defense mechanisms. The developed labs have been adopted in various security related courses in numerous colleges in the United States and other countries. In the last 24 months, the platform has logged over 2,000 new users/visitors from all over the world (about 115 countries), with about 39% from the United States. Many results have been published in top-notched journals and conferences including IEEE Communications Magazine, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, IEEE Transactions on Communications, IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security, IEEE Internet of Things Journal, Society for Information Technology & Teacher Education International Conference, etc. We have also presented our developed labs to local high school students to increase the awareness of wireless threats and defense mechanisms. 

The outcomes of this research broadly impact the education and training on mobile security technologies and applications. The developed learning materials are accessible, meaningful, and affordable for students at both undergraduate and graduate levels. They not only have been by the PIs? institutions but also learners at large. The state-of-the-art technologies in mobile security inspire many students to do research in these areas. It is worth mentioning that some PhD students partially supported by this project have finished their dissertations and become tenure-track assistant professors right after graduation, and a few undergraduate students chose to attend graduate school to continue doing research in the areas of cybersecurity.

Modified by: Liran Ma
